resources.string: AntiLitter

The average person generates 
 over 4 pounds of trash 
 every day and about 1.5 tons 
 of solid waste per year.

Nearly all litter ends up in 
 the ocean. It is predicted 
 by the year 2050 that there 
 will be more pounds of plastic 
 in the ocean than fish.

The most littered item is fast 
 food packaging. The chance 
 of people littering these kinds 
 of items increases greatly 
 on highways.

One million birds and 100 thousand 
 sea animals are killed 
 every year as a result of 
 being trapped in or eating 
 some litter item.

Littering is illegal. Fines vary 
 by state and by city and 
 county, you will be charged 
 if you are caught littering.

Litter is very expensive. Every 
 year millions of taxpayer’s 
 dollars are spent cleaning 
 up litter.

Litter spoils water quality. The 
 hazardous waste seeps into 
 soil and can cause groundwater 
 pollution.
Litter can lead to animal attacks \n as animals are drawn closer \n to civilization.
About 25,000 car accidents in \n the US are caused by litter \n each year.

70% of the billions of pounds 
 of litter that end up in the 
 world's waterways sinks straight to 
 the bottom harming the animals 
 and plants that live on the 
 ocean floor.
One littered plastic bottle \n can take 450 years to \n decompose.
South Carolina contributes the \n most litter and Washington \n state contributes the least.

Litter contributes to the 
 Great Pacific Garbage Patch, 
 which is an extremely large 
 island made of trash 
 estimated to be anywhere from 
 270,000 to 5.8 million square 
 miles floating in the Pacific 
 Ocean.
Motorists account for 53% \n of all litter produced \n annually.

The 5 most common littered 
 items found in coastal cleanups 
 around the world are: plastic 
 cigarette butts, food wrappers, 
 plastic beverage bottles, 
 plastic bottle caps, and plastic 
 straws and drink stirrers.

Litter contributes to the 
 15 to 51 trillion particles 
 of floating micro plastics in 
 our oceans, weighing between 
 205-520 million pounds. Micro 
 plastics are too small to 
 be filtered out by many 
 wastewater treatment plants.

Approximately every square 
 mile of ocean has more than 
 45,000 pieces of plastic 
 floating in it.

Fish and other marine life 
 often can’t tell the difference 
 between littered plastic and food. 
 If the animal eats plastic, 
 they can’t digest it. The 
 plastic fills their stomachs, 
 and they starve to death.
Approximately one truckload \n of plastic enters the ocean \n every single minute.

Littered styrofoam takes 80 
 years, littered aluminum takes 
 200 years, and littered 
 plastic takes 400 years 
 to decompose.
